intro: Touchardia occidentalis, commonly known as the western touchardia, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of central and southern Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and robust, hairy stems. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, with lance-shaped leaves that are covered in fine pubescence. Its flowers are yellow and arranged in clusters, producing small, achene fruits that are dispersed by wind. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky habitats.
